Each and every Labor member has stood in this place this morning and derided the 30 per cent rebate, which provides about $750 to every Australian family with private cover. Private health insurance will always be 30 per cent cheaper under the coalition. Unfortunately, I do not have the statistics at the moment for the individual electorates around the country showing the numbers of people who have taken out private health cover and the numbers of people who take advantage of the government's private health insurance rebate. The honourable members who spoke on behalf of the opposition—the members for Lowe, Bruce, Stirling, Throsby and Shortland—would be shocked to know of the thousands of people in each of their electorates who have private health insurance. Those people will exact their revenge at the next election when they hear Labor members get up and deride this rebate from the Australian government, which enables many more people to take out private health insurance. I just so happen to have had handed to me information relating to private health insurance participation in New South Wales by electorate. The honourable member for Lowe was not supportive of private health insurance, yet he has thousands of people in his electorate who are strongly supportive of it.
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 11.48 a.m. to 12.02 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before I was abruptly interrupted by the division in the main chamber, I was talking about how members opposite are not speaking for their electorates when they fail to be entirely supportive of the private health insurance rebate. I think it would benefit the chamber if I advise it of the level of support for private health insurance in a number of electorates represented by members of the Australian Labor Party. The member for Lowe has 64.34 per cent of his people in private health insurance; the member for Bruce, 47.71 per cent; the member for Stirling, 59.49 per cent—almost 60 per cent; the member for Throsby, 35.23 per cent; and the member for Shortland, 40.82 per cent.

speech.para: It goes without saying that, if it were not for the government's private health insurance rebate, many of these people in Labor electorates would simply be unable to afford private health insurance. I believe that it is important that members of parliament listen to what their constituencies are saying, and it is really vital that their representations in fact reflect what people want. In my view, it is utterly despicable for the ALP to be less than entirely supportive of a system that has brought about private health insurance affordability to so many Australians.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to ask a question of the parliamentary secretary.
(Mr Barresi)—Parliamentary Secretary, will you allow a question?
—Yes.

—Parliamentary Secretary, isn't a major difference between private health funds under Labor and private health funds under this government the fact that penalty charges are paid if people drop in and out?

—What this government has done is to put a platform under the loss of people from private health insurance. I suppose there is a carrot and stick arrangement. We have sought to encourage people back into private health insurance. We have sought to make it obvious to them that they benefit if they remain in private health insurance and that they do not just join private health insurance at a stage in their life when they are high users of the system. The member for Stirling was referring to Lifetime Health Cover, and I am pleased to advise her that that is also the policy of the Australian Labor Party.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to ask a question of the member for Kingston or the member for Shortland. There seems to be some substantial confusion.
—Member for Dunkley, that is out of order. You can only seek to ask a question of the parliamentary secretary.
—I will, then. Parliamentary Secretary, there seems to be some confusion about—
—Member for Dunkley, you address your question through the chair. Are you seeking to ask a question?
—Yes, I am.
—Parliamentary Secretary, will you allow a question?
—I will.

—Parliamentary Secretary, the members opposite, the member for Shortland and the member for Kingston, were confused about the ALP's policy. Is it clear that the ALP is supporting Lifetime Health Cover and private health insurance? The comments from across the way seemed to be quite different.

—I would like to thank the member for Dunkley for his very perceptive question. He is a very strong supporter of private health insurance, of the rebate, and of making it affordable for ordinary, decent Australians to take out private health insurance. To answer the member's question, it is a fact that the Australian Labor Party technically supports Lifetime Health Cover, but unfortunately many of the remarks by Labor members in this debate indicate that they are unsupportive of the private health insurance rebate which, in effect, makes private health insurance attainable for their constituents.
—That would be at risk under Labor.

—It certainly would be at risk under Labor, as the member for Dunkley has correctly pointed out. Because there are undoubtedly going to be further divisions in the main chamber, I just want to sum up by saying that this is a very important piece of legislation. I thank all honourable members for backing this legislation. I think, however, it is regrettable that the Australian Labor Party has seen fit to criticise the government when this government has made private health insurance affordable for more Australians and, in doing so, has also been able to make sure that the public health system is viable. A very vibrant private health insurance system means that the public health system remains viable, and that is particularly important.

speech.para: Before I sit down, the member for Shortland did refer to bulk-billing. The government does recognise that there has been a decline in bulk-billing. However, some 73 per cent of services provided by general practitioners are bulk-billed and, for people over the age of 65, over 80 per cent of the services are bulk-billed. So, while there has been a reduction, there is still a substantial, high proportion of services being bulk-billed. I commend the bill to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Treasury Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 contains a minor amendment, and Labor will support it. The amendment clarifies the operation of two acts: the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act 2001 and the General Insurance Reform Act 2001. The collection of data act sought to improve the quality of data that APRA collects from financial agencies for the purposes of prudential supervision. The General Insurance Reform Act sought to strengthen the prudential supervision regime for general insurers. This new bill does just one thing. It makes it clear that the provisions of the collection of data act commence immediately before the provisions of the General Insurance Reform Act. This will ensure that, where the same provisions of the Insurance Act 1973 are amended by both acts, the collection of data amendments operate first.

speech.para: The relevant provisions of the Insurance Act relate to the role, accountability and responsibility of auditors and actuaries, access to premises and the signing of documents. However, this bill has come before the House because of two careless errors by the government. The collection of data act was to commence on a date to be fixed by proclamation. The government duly proclaimed that the bill would commence on 1 October 2001. However, the proclamation was invalid. The government then proclaimed that the bill would commence on 1 July 2002, the same date that the General Insurance Reform Act commenced. However, in doing so, they failed to notice that this would create an ambiguity as to which act commenced first.
Labor will support this bill, but urges the government to exercise greater care in the future and not waste this chamber's valuable time correcting their careless mistakes.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Kingston for his support of this particular legislation. The purpose of this bill, the Treasury Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002, is to clarify the operation of two acts—and the member for Kingston referred to that in his speech—the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act 2001 and the General Insurance Reform Act 2001.

speech.para: The bill is of a minor and technical nature and is designed to ensure that these two acts have their intended effects. The Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act and the General Insurance Reform Act both amended the Insurance Act 1973 for different purposes. The Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act, among other things, amended the Insurance Act to enable modernisation of APRA's data collections from general insurance companies. The General Insurance Reform Act amended the Insurance Act to substantially strengthen the prudential supervisory requirements for general insurers operating in Australia.

The provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act which amended the Insurance Act and the General Insurance Reform Act both commenced on 1 July this year. It had originally been intended that the provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act amending the Insurance Act would commence on 1 October last year, in advance of the commencement of the General Insurance Reform Act. A proclamation was made to the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act with this intent.

On this basis, the General Insurance Reform Act was drafted as though the provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act which amended the Insurance Act had already commenced. However, it was subsequently determined that, due to a technical difficulty, the proclamation of the provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act which purported to amend the Insurance Act was ineffective. As a result, another effective proclamation was made. The effect of this was that the two acts, both amending the Insurance Act, and in some cases the same provisions of the Insurance Act, commenced on the same day.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to ask a question of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration.
(Mr Barresi)—Parliamentary Secretary, will you take the question?
—Yes.

—Would the parliamentary secretary concede that these were in fact errors—that the government not only did not get it right the first time but did not get it right at its second go—and that we are now back fixing the problem?
—I think that my friend opposite is being a little harsh. Really, this is more a matter of finetuning.

speech.para: This has introduced some uncertainty as to which amendments to the Insurance Act were designed to commence first. This bill makes it clear that the amendments to the Insurance Act contained in the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act commenced before the amendments contained in the General Insurance Reform Act. I commend this particular bill also to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What is his Department's estimate of foreigners working illegally in Australia each year from 1996 to 2001.
(2) How many illegal visa overstaying foreigners were removed each year from 1996 to 2001.
(3) What was the cost of locating and removing over stayers each year from 1996 to 2001.
(4) What departmental measures have been taken to reduce the number of over stayers.
(5) Does this Department plan a crackdown on the location and removal of overstayers; if so, what is the extent of the proposed measures.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) It is not possible to provide a meaningful estimate of the number of non-citizens working illegally in Australia at any given point in time. This is because some non-citizens will have valid visas but be breaching conditions attached to those visas, whilst others will be working while they have overstayed their visa or are otherwise illegally in Australia.

However in March 1999 the Government appointed an external Reference Group to guide a review of the issue of illegal workers in Australia. The Reference Group's report, entitled `Review of Illegal Workers in Australia' was released in November 1999.

In the report the Reference Group estimated that 50 per cent of unlawful non-citizens are working illegally. The Reference Group also noted that the number of lawful visitors working in breach of their visa conditions was unknown.

Based on the estimate of the Reference Group I provide the following table. The table covers estimates of overstayers and the consequent number of Illegal Workers going back to the year 2000. Overstayer figures prior to 2000 were derived using a different, less accurate methodology than that currently being used and are not statistically comparable to the current estimates.

(2) The table below provides the number of unlawful non-citizens and people breaching their visa conditions who have left Australia as a result of Departmental compliance action in the years 1995/1996 to 2001/2002. These figures exclude fishermen, stowaways, smugglers, deserters and unauthorised boat arrivals.

(3) Because of the wide range of other activities done in the compliance program (for example employer information, program integrity checking, visa cancellation and the removal of unauthorised boat arrivals) it is not possible to derive actual costs associated solely with the location and removal of overstayers.

However to give some indication of the costs involved in the first eleven months of 2001/2002 it is estimated that my Department spent just under $30m in locating a total of 15,892 persons. For the same period it is estimated that approximately $14m was spent on removing 9,852 persons (this includes unlawful non-citizens, people breaching their visa conditions, fishermen, stowaways, smugglers, deserters and unauthorised boat arrivals).

(4) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) is actively working on a number of onshore and offshore measures to reduce the number of overstayers in Australia. These measures include:
· A network of specialist compliance officers located overseas to liaise with authorities such as local police and immigration officers to combat the number of people arriving in Australia illegally.

· In association with other Government agencies, measures to enhance border surveillance systems and deter illegal migration. The whole-of-government approach to preventing people smuggling and illegal migration has ensured that attempted breaches of Australian borders are detected and intercepted.

· Onshore compliance officers undertake regular field operations in both metropolitan areas and rural areas of Australia. Some of the field operations are organised in conjunction with other agencies such as Federal/State police, Centrelink and ATO officers.

· The development of successful relationships with employers, educational institutions, and other Government agencies to gain the cooperation of the Australian community in assisting the Department locate overstayers.

· Compliance teams are set up which target certain risk areas identified for the program. As examples such teams may focus on illegal worker and employer awareness campaigns, failed ministerial intervention applications, failed appeals to merits review tribunals and student compliance.

· Implementation of a number of the recommendations of the Review of Illegal Workers in Australia. These include measures to discourage employers from employing illegal workers, including overstayers, as well as information to assist employers to identify illegal workers.

(5) DIMIA plans to maintain its active and ongoing program of detection and removal of overstayers and persons breaching their visa conditions. These people are located through our regular field operations and through the action of Federal, State and Territory police forces and other agencies.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the Government's announced sale of Point Cook Airfield, (a) is the Government intending to offer the property for sale as freehold or leasehold and (b) what have been the considerations given to the alternative forms of sale.
(2) What is the anticipated sale price.
(3) When does the Government anticipate the property will formally be offered for sale.
(4) What national or international environmental classifications are associated directly or indirectly with the Point Cook site.
(5) What specific environmental audit or audits of the site have been commissioned by or on behalf of the Defence Estates Organisation.
(6) Has the Government discussed the environmental condition of the site with the Victorian Environment Protection Authority.
(7) How does the Government intend to deal with any potential findings of environmental contamination of the site ahead of the sale being finalised.
(8) What is the current value of the RAAF Museum collection at Point Cook.
(9) What annual funding has been allocated by the Government or the RAAF to the RAAF Point Cook Museum in each year between 1990 and 2001.

(10) How does the Government intend for the RAAF Museum to continue operations within a privately owned site, and what funding will the Government, either through the RAAF or other sources, deliver recurrently to the RAAF Museum.

(11) Has the Government had any discussions with Victorian Government museum representatives about the relationship that might be developed between the RAAF Point Cook Museum and other museums in Victoria.
(12) What provision is being made for the upgrading of electricity, sewerage and road services to the Point Cook site ahead of its sale.
(13) How many RAAF personnel were housed on the Point Cook site at 1 August 2002, and how many of the children of the RAAF personnel attend the Point Cook Primary School.
(14) When does the Government envisage RAAF personnel will depart the Point Cook site.
(15) What are the current air traffic control arrangements at Point Cook.
(16) What are the minimum air traffic control arrangements that the Government will require for any private owner to maintain.

(17) What provision will be made for changes in minimum air traffic control arrangements at Point Cook if, after the date of sale, recommendations are made for increased control services out of the late-July 2002 collision and fatality at Moorabbin airport.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) and (b) Initial planning anticipated the disposal of the site was as a freehold sale. Defence is currently considering a proposal for a leasehold sale and a recommendation will be provided to the Government once that consideration has been finalised.

(2) Defence has not yet sought a market valuation for the property from an independent authority such as the Australian Valuation Office. A market valuation will be sought once the property is ready for marketing. The valuation will be commercial-in-confidence as its release may prejudice the sale price.
(3) It is anticipated the property will be offered for sale in the 2002/03 financial year, although revenue is not anticipated until the 2003/04 financial year.

(4) It is understood that the environmental classifications associated with the Point Cook site are covered by the Register of the National Estate, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act and the Victoria Planning and Environment Act.

(5) In January 1996, a Victorian EPA Accredited Environmental Auditor - Contaminated Land, undertook a Statutory Environmental Audit of a 6.159 ha portion of the site as part of a proposal to establish the National Air & Space Museum of Australia. Additionally, there have been a number of other environmental and related assessments conducted on the site, which are currently being reviewed.
(6) Yes.

(7) Defence is undertaking further investigation to complement the existing environmental information and gain a comprehensive understanding of issues on the property. Where appropriate, Defence will undertake remediation consistent with future land use; however, all information on the site condition will be made available to potential purchasers.
(8) A major stocktake program is currently underway to catalogue and value the RAAF heritage collection. It is currently conservatively valued at $40million.
(9) Annual operating allocations for RAAF Museum, excluding salaries, have been:

(10) It is intended that the precinct occupied by RAAF Museum will remain under a form of Commonwealth control after the sale of Point Cook. It is anticipated that recurrent Museum funding will remain consistent with current funding levels.

(11) RAAF Museum works closely with the Australian War Memorial in regard to advice and expertise on aircraft and technical equipment. RAAF Museum has a working relationship with other institutions, such as the Museum of Victoria, in providing advice on technical equipment that may be acquired by those institutions.
(12) No consideration has been afforded to the upgrade of these services. Defence is disposing of the site on an “as is” basis.

(13) As at 15 August 2002 (figures as at 1 August 2002 not readily available) there were 19 Defence families occupying married quarters on Point Cook base, not all of whom are posted to RAAF Williams, and 126 single or unaccompanied members, predominantly students, occupying single living-in accommodation. Defence does not maintain data on the schools attended by Defence personnel. However, I understand that there are approximately 10-12 Defence children at Point Cook Primary School.

(14) The majority of RAAF personnel will depart the site when the RAAF College is relocated by approximately 2005. A small cadre of RAAF personnel will remain within RAAF Museum and Australian Airforce Cadet billets on the site indefinitely.

(15) The Point Cook airfield is an unlicensed airfield. Aircraft using the airfield are required to have signed an Airfield Use Agreement and have it lodged with KFPW, Defence's property manager for leases and licences at the site. An Airfield Manager contracted by Defence monitors air movements. The air traffic control tower is not in operation. The current air traffic control arrangements are for Mandatory Broadcast Zone operations.

(16) The Commonwealth will not have any minimum air traffic control arrangements. Air movements after the sale of the property will be the responsibility of the new owner. The Wyndham City Council has advised that it has adopted a figure of 100,000 movements per year for planning purposes in the area. Defence has incorporated this figure into one of the scenarios developed in considering the possible future strategic land use. Any formal air traffic arrangement will be the responsibility of the State and/or local government.
(17) This will be an issue for the new owner and the State authorities to determine.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

(2) What specific improvements in Telstra services have been achieved in the Gippsland South region over the past 12 months, and what is the methodology for demonstrating any improvement.

Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question based on information provided by Telstra:

answer.para: The Customer Service Guarantee (CSG) is part of the Government's comprehensive regulatory safety-net. The CSG requires telephone companies to meet specified timeframes for the connection and repair of telephone services for residential and small business customers, or pay compensation. Timeframes under the CSG for service connection have been progressively tightened since its introduction.

Compliance with the CSG has been used as an indicator of service performance in relation to new connections (Service Activations) and fault repairs (Service Assurance) in the following answer. It should be noted that CSG performance can be adversely affected by factors outside Telstra's control such as extreme weather and other seasonal factors, especially when looking at defined geographical areas.
The following figures provided by Telstra are based on Telstra's Service Regions.
(1) Telstra has advised that CSG compliance figures for Service Assurance in the Albury/Wodonga Region improved from 85.5% in April 2002 to 92.5% as at June 2002.
Over the same period CSG figures for Service Activation moved from 92% to 94.8%.

(2) CSG performance for Service Assurance in the Gippsland Region averaged 93.1% for the period July to November 2001. In December 2001, the Gippsland Service Area was expanded to include the Seymour area and is now known at the South Eastern Service Delivery Area. From December 2001 to June 2002, CSG Assurance performance for the South Eastern Service Delivery area averaged 93.3%.

CSG performance for Service Activation in the Gippsland Region averaged 95.8% for the period July to November 2001. In December 2001, the Gippsland Service Area was expanded to include the Seymour area and is now known as the South Eastern Service Delivery area. From December 2001 to June 2002, CSG Activation performance for the South Eastern Service Delivery area averaged 95.3%.
(3) The eastern and northern suburbs of Melbourne are serviced by one Telstra service region. This area is bounded by Ferntree Gully and Kinglake in the east and Coburg and Sunbury in the west.

quote.para: Telstra has advised that CSG performance for Service Assurance in this area has improved from 91% in January 2002 to 97% at June 2002. CSG figures for Service Activation rose from 94% in January 2002 to 95% as at June 2002.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Uniforms and Equipment
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 778)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Are Australian Defence Force personnel issued with all uniforms and equipment free of charge when beginning their training.
(2) If so, can personnel swap worn out, lost or damaged uniforms and equipment on a one for one basis or are they required to pay for all new uniforms and equipment after their initial issue.
(3) If personnel are forced to pay for their own replacement uniforms and equipment are they able to claim it back on tax; if not, why not.

(4) Is it the case that the families of (a) Navy personnel deployed on operations overseas are able to send mail for no cost up to 3kg, (b) Army personnel deployed on operations overseas are able to send mail for no cost up to 2kg and (c) Air Force personnel deployed on operations overseas are able to send mail for no cost up to 1kg; if so, (d) why are the weights at which families can send mail different for the different services and (e) what action does the Minister intend to take to remedy these discrepancies.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) After the initial free issue, a Uniform Maintenance Allowance is paid to assist members to maintain an approved scale of uniforms in good order and condition. However, provisions exist for field uniforms and equipment that are worn out or damaged due to everyday wear and tear to be exchanged on a one for one basis unless they are lost or damaged through the members' negligence. In that case replacement of the items must be paid for by the member.

Reserve Australian Defence Force members, not on continuous full-time duty, are issued replacement clothing and equipment on a one for one basis. Again, loss or damage of uniforms due to the members negligence requires replacement costs to be met by the member.

(3) Uniform Maintenance Allowance is paid to eligible Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel fortnightly as a non-taxed allowance. Personnel are required to justify expenditure on uniform and uniform-related items in their taxation returns at the end of each financial year as per normal work-related clothing deduction arrangements. ADF personnel in receipt of the Uniform Maintenance Allowance are required to pay tax on any amount of the allowance that cannot be substantiated as expended on the maintenance of their uniforms.

(4) `Free' mail limits for ADF personnel deployed overseas do not differ between the three Services. These limits are set by Commander Australian Theatre, in consultation with others, including Australia Post. These limits are based on the nature and location of the operation, as well as logistic support considerations.

The cost of sending mail to ADF personnel deployed on operations is subsidised by Defence. The rate of subsidy is determined as a component of the conditions of service for each operation, and thus varies between operations. Currently, operations in East Timor and the Australian contribution to the war on terrorism attract the highest subsidies.

For example, a package of up to 20kgs can be sent free of charge to East Timor, where the same package to a member serving in Israel would be charged at the Australian domestic rate applicable from the point of lodgment in Sydney. Mail or packages for personnel deployed as part of the Australian contribution to the war on terrorism are only free up to a limit of 1kg. Anything over 1kg is charged at the Australian domestic rate applicable from the point of lodgment to Sydney.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) to (6)The NSW State Government is primarily responsible for the delivery of drug and alcohol services in NSW. Information about services available in the areas specified will need to be provided by the NSW State Government.

(7) Under the National Illicit Drugs Strategy the Commonwealth Government provides funding for prevention and treatment of illicit drug use through the Non-Government Organisation (NGO) Treatment Grants Program, the Community Partnerships Initiative and the Council of Australian Government's (COAG) Drug Diversion Initiative. Details of the funding provided under these programs in the wider Illawarra area is at Attachment A.
ATTACHMENT A
Funding Provided by the Commonwealth Government to projects in the Throsby electorate and wider Illawarra area under the National Illicit Drug Strategy
NGO Treatment Grants Program:

entry.para: The Family Intervention Project is an education, support and counselling service aimed at improving the mental health and functioning capacity of illicit substance abusers, their partners and other family members.

The development and implementation of intervention and treatment programs for youth at risk of continuance of substance use problems and for youth in need of structured residential and non-residential treatment for problematic substance use and high levels of problem behaviour. Particular focus on those with a dual diagnosis.
Extension of drug intervention and treatment services within the overall Triple Care Farm program targeted at marginalised young people.
Increase staffing levels to secure the provision of existing residential services, meeting best practice guidelines and to develop ambulatory detoxification service.

quote.para: Community Partnerships Initiative:

entry.para: The “Youth Drug Education and Programs Team” project aims to invite young women (15-24 years) to participate in a prevention education training program. Ongoing workshops will equip them with skills and knowledge in team work skills, program planning etc. The participants will then form the “Youth Drugs Prevention Advisory Team” that will aim to develop strategies and programs to assess needs; disseminate information about the Team and the aims of the project.

This project aims to further develop and evaluate the TANDEM Training Program for parents in outer-metropolitan, rural and remote communities. The program is based on the premise that prevention and early intervention must increase young people's personal and environmental resilience for protection against risk of drug and alcohol misuse.

quote.para: COAG Drug Diversion Initiative:

entry.para: Suitable adult offenders who have illicit drug abuse as the precipitating factor for the offence.
Magistrates Early Referral Into Treatment (MERIT)Assessment and outpatient case management and counselling through the Illawarra Area Health Service.

quote.para: There are a number of other Statewide programs funded under the Diversion Initiative that provide funding for police cautioning and treatment to divert offenders from the criminal justice system and give an opportunity for drug users to access education and/or treatment. These programs include the:

Young Offenders' Act - This Scheme applies to children apprehended by police for a wholly summary drug offence involving not more than the statutory small quantity of the drug, or for an offence that is drug-related. This means police, in appropriate circumstances, can issue a caution or warning, or organise a youth justice conference in lieu of commencing court proceedings and

Cannabis Cautioning Scheme - The Scheme provides police officers with the discretion to caution adult offenders in relation to the use and possession of dried cannabis and the possession of equipment for the administration of cannabis. A person can only be cautioned if they have no prior convictions for drug offences or offences of violence or sexual assault.

Offenders are given written legal and health information on the use of cannabis. The caution also lists the dedicated cannabis phone line for the Alcohol and Drug Information Service (ADIS). From 1 September 2001, NSW Police commenced the issue of Second Caution Notices where offenders are required to contact ADIS to undertake a mandatory health education session on the use of cannabis.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) What was the sale price of the Defence property known as Chicquita Park, located at Levanto Street, Mentone, Vic., sold in December 2001.
(2) On what date was (a) the property sold and (b) the sale price agreed upon by the Minister's Department and the purchaser.
(3) What conditions, if any, applied to the sale.
(4) How many tenderers submitted a bid.
(5) Was the price in the tender of the eventual purchaser the highest price of all tenders.
(6) By what process did the Minister's Department satisfy itself that the final price agreed with the purchaser was a reasonable price for the property.
(7) During negotiations with Kingston Council prior to the sale of Chicquita Park, what estimated value did the Minister's Department place on the property.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Due to confidentiality limitations, it is inappropriate for Defence to disclose the sale price of individual properties.
(2) (a) Contracts were exchanged on 20 December 2001 and settlement occurred on 20 March 2002.
(b) The price was agreed on 20 December 2001 when a deposit was accepted on the exchange of contracts.
(3) The only condition of sale was that the purchaser offered a lease of up to three years to the Mentone Scout Group.
(4) Five conforming tenders and four non-conforming tenders were received.
(6) The department obtained a valuation from a certified valuer in June 2001 indicating a market value for the site of between $2,000,000 and $2,500,000.
(7) A valuation based on a residential zoning was obtained in 1999 and the market value of the property at that time was estimated at $2,900,000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 21 August 2002:

question.para: (1) How many secondary movement relocation (class 451) visas has the government issued to date to successful asylum seekers.
(2) What were the countries of origin of these visa holders.
(3) Of those issued a secondary movement relocation visa, how many were (a) partners and (b) children of temporary protection visa holders who are already in Australia.

(4) Are temporary protection visas for 3 years duration and Secondary Movement Relocation visas for 5 years; if so, does this mean that the Government proposes to review separately, and at different times, the continuing need for protection of individual family members.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) As at 6 September 2002, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) had issued 119 Secondary Movement Relocation (subclass 451) (SMR) visas:
· 34 SMR visas were issued to persons residing in Indonesia; and
· 85 SMR visas were issued to persons residing in Nauru.
(2) As at 6 September 2002, DIMIA had issued SMR visas to:
· 107 Iraqi nationals;
· 1 Iranian national;
· 3 Afghani nationals;
· 4 Palestinian nationals; and
· 4 stateless persons.
(3) As at 6 September 2002 of the 119 persons issued with SMR visas:
(a) 31 were partners of Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) holders already in Australia; and
(b) 66 were minors with a parent TPV holder already in Australia.
(4) TPVs are issued for a period of 3 years and SMR visas are issued for a period of 5 years.

It is possible that members of a single family unit who have arrived in Australia under different circumstances or at different times have been issued with different temporary humanitarian visa types with different expiry dates. It is therefore possible that they may have any subsequent claims for ongoing protection considered at different times. However, holders of these visas in Australia are able to lodge further applications for protection at any time and the Minister is able to decide such applications at any time. Opportunities thus exist for the Minister to align the terms of visas subsequently granted to family groups, if appropriate, should they apply together.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 August 2002:

question.para: (1) What is the full year budget cost of the office of the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force following the appointment of the Acting Justice of the Supreme Court, Justice Peter Newsman, to the position.
(2) When will the Director of Military Prosecutions be appointed.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of Channel Nines Sunday programs claim that 13% of oil for food revenue is to be distributed to the Kurdish population in Northern Iraq.
(2) Is he able to say why the World Health Organisation (WHO) allows Baghdad to distribute or not distribute medicines brought under the oil for food program to the Kurdish region.
(3) Is he able to say whether US$250 million is being earmarked for Kurdistan per annum, and about $200 million per annum remains in accounts controlled by the regime in Iraq.
(4) Is he also able to say whether there are widespread shortages of key medicines in Kurdistan and Northern Iraq.
(5) Has the Australian Government had representatives visit Kurdistan since the establishment of the northern no fly zone.
(6) Has the Australian Government made representations to the WHO about the more equitable distribution of the oil for food plan; if not, why not.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. United Nations' resolutions stipulate that 13 per cent of total revenue from the Oil-for-Food Programme will fund the humanitarian programme in the three northern governorates of Iraq.

(2) The United Nations Inter-Agency Humanitarian Programme is responsible for the storage, handling, internal transportation, distribution and confirmation of equitable distribution of humanitarian supplies in the three northern governorates. Distribution is not undertaken in these three northern governorates by the Iraqi Regime.

(3) Money raised from the Oil-for-Food Programme is placed into UN escrow accounts and is not controlled by the Iraqi Regime. The total annual revenue collected by the Oil-for-Food Programme, 13 per cent of which funds the humanitarian programme for the three northern governorates, fluctuates depending on oil sales made by Iraq and changes in oil price.

(4) Yes. A UN Secretary-General report released in November 2001 pursuant to UNSCR 1360 indicates significant shortages of domestically produced medicines and medical supplies, and periodic shortages of imported medicines and medical supplies in the three northern governorates.
(5) Yes.

(6) No. According to a technical report prepared by the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the UN in 2000, improvements in the nutritional situation in the north started in 1994, prior to UNSCR 986 (1995). This is due to greater resources in the north - the north has 9 per cent of the land area of Iraq but nearly 50 per cent of the productive arable land - and receives higher levels of assistance per person. The north also benefits from the greater flexibility the use of cash gives agencies for the more effective operation and management of programmes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether in July 2002 there were mass demonstrations in Tehran calling for the end of the Islamic Republic.
(2) Is he able to say whether six leading members of Irans notorious Revolutionary Guard issued a communiqué in support of the people of Iran.
(3) Is he able to say whether the Grand Ayatollah Taheri of Esfehan openly sided with student demonstrators, calling on the ruling theocracy to give up power.

(4) Is he able to say whether Ayatollah Taheris announcement against the tyranny of the current Iranian regime also included a defence of Ayatollah Montazeri, one of the most outspoken domestic critics of Iran who has been under house arrest for years.
(5) Is he able to say whether Ayatollah Taheris announcement applauded Montazeris fatwah or ruling against the practice of suicide bombing.

(6) Is he able to say whether ayatollahs from Qom have been in clandestine contact with the son of the late Shah of Iran asking him to send cassettes verbalizing a message of non-violent civil disobedience against the regime.

(7) Is he able to say whether during the demonstrations, the Iranian police force was confined to barracks and foreigners with paramilitary training, chiefly Palestinian and Iraqi Arabs, and Uzbeks and Tadzhiks from Afghanistan, were sent to beat the demonstrators down.
(8) Is he also able to say whether during these demonstrations the protestors also denounced President Mohammad Khatami.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) On 9 July 2002 there were demonstrations in Tehran of an estimated 4,000 people protesting ongoing imprisonment of student leaders arrested three years previously and calling for increased freedom and greater regard for human rights.
(2) I am unaware of any such communiqué.
(4) Yes.
(6) I have no evidence to substantiate or discount such a claim.
(8) Yes.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Managed Migration—Who Does the Managing
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 900)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 2002:

question.para: Did he recently circulate a colour brochure on his presentation entitled, “Managed Migration - Who does the Managing?”; if so, (a) what sum did the brochure cost to produce, (b) what was its print run and (c) to whom was it circulated.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Yes, a colour booklet was produced by my Department containing an edited version of a presentation I made to senior government officials and academics in the United Kingdom on 16 August 2002.
(a) The booklet cost $2,025.68 to produce.
(b) To date 453 copies of the booklet have been printed.

(c) The booklet was distributed to media at a press conference I held on Thursday 22 August 2002. It was subsequently circulated to all Members and Senators and is available to the public on my website <www.minister.immi.gov.au>. In addition, approximately 50 copies of the booklet were used for internal purposes.
